in the wargaming scene but I am willing to bet many of you have never seen it

gonna show you an alternative way my version of this classic build these are
a fantastic way to really add some dynamic excitement to your table if you
are doing a big epic battle or there's a town under siege whatever it may be
putting these simple little flame marker smoke things on your table is going to
cause a lot of excitement I promise the best part about this build is that it
does not use any expensive material hard to find material complicated and tools
expensive tools nothing it is really simple and straightforward and you can
pick up everything to make this tools included at a store like Walmart and in
fact a lot of the materials can actually come straight from the dollar store if
you have a hard time finding foam or some of the other stuff that I use don't
worry it's not involved in this build let's start a fire the foundation for
this build are those cheap LED flickering candle tea lights that you
can pick up at the dollar store not these ones that change colors but these
ones the ones the just have the yellow kind of candle
flicker pick up a bunch of these you're also gonna need some polyester stuffing
or filler I got mine at Walmart there's a lot of different types of stuffing but
you're looking for this stuff they're really fibrous polyester stuff and not
the cotton that's more in balls you want to remove the rubber piece covering the
led so that it shines a bit brighter then take a clump of this polyester
filler and just hot glue it to the tea light use a bunch of glue here make a
little indent and squish it in in a shape that is kind of reminiscent of
smoke then take them outside and spray-paint them using the cheapest flat
black spray-paint that you can get your hands on you're gonna want to apply more
paint towards the bottom and less towards the top this will make them look
a little bit more airy and a little bit more like an actual bonfire you may also
find that once this dries it's hardened up the poly filler a bit but not as much
as you might want so adding another coating of a clear coat will stiffen
these up even more you can use any clear coat but I use this Mod Podge stuff just
because it's horrible and it really is not good for any other purposes
once the poly filler is painted it's a good idea to attach it a little bit
better to the teal I eat now that it's more solid you can get a better bond you
might need to give it a bit of a haircut so that the excess sits nice and flat on
the bottom of these smoke pieces and that's it this is the full basic method
for creating tea light smoke markers really really simple
however like me you may want to make a set with more decorative bases and
there's two reasons for this one is that it can look pretty cool but two is that
it gives it a solid heavy footing for this kind of light poly filler to sit on
so that you can actually grab the pieces by the base and not constantly be
squishing this you know soft poly filler so to do this I'm
going to channel my inner DM Scottie and I'm just gonna use some toilet paper
water and PVA glue to create an earthlike mound around the tea lights
this is about as cheap and easy as it gets all you have to do is wet some
toilet paper put some PVA glue on it add some more water and sculpt it into place
you can keep adding glue and toilet paper until you get it looking the way
you want it to look you can immediately coat these things in sand and gravel you
don't have to wait for the toilet paper concoction to dry first which is nice
however the kind of crappy downside to this method is that overall this toilet
paper takes an incredibly long time to dry one way you can speed up the process
however is by putting the pieces in a hot vehicle to sort of bake and
accelerate the drying time and while those are drying you can get to work on
making the Timbers that will feed these bonfires I used a mixture of popsicle
sticks coffee stirrers and bamboo skewers this gave me some variance in
the size and shape of wood that I was using I made them look more like timber
by roughing them up with a rotary tool but you don't need to use a fancy rotary
tool you could just use a knife for this the goal here is to make them not look
like popsicle sticks I pre painted all of the wood using a very watered-down
dark brown just like I did in my ruined Tower video once the toilet paper mounds
were dry I put some hot glue on the bottom of them and press them into some
parchment paper this gives you a nice flat kind of rubberized surface on the
bottom side of your terrain I'm using a new glue gun here that was sent to me by
a viewer thanks will so far I really liked it but this is the first project
I've used it on once I've had some more time with it I'll give you guys a review
of it to paint these things I was able to prime them using a flat black spray
paint because there's nothing on these that would melt and you may have noticed
that unlike the first batch I've left the rubber LED
flame cover thing on these and that's because it acted as a perfect mask when
spray-painting these once the spray-painting was done I cut them away
and I revealed just the led so that these would be as bright as possible
I kept the paint job really simple on these I just gave them a dry brushing of
a gray and then another dry brushing of a white I wanted these to look more like
ash than rubble the only kind of extra painting I did on these was I took some
very vibrant orange and I did a little bit of really basic object source
lighting and dabbed on some of this orange II paint around the flame to kind
of enhance that look once the painting was done I could take the wood that I
had pre-made and start breaking it into smaller pieces and gluing it in place on
this mound I did do a little bit of dry brushing with a black to make it look a
little bit charred and then a little bit of that same bright orange to give it a
bit of the glow from the fire I pre painted some Tufts of the polyester
filler black and I was able to then glue them in place once that was all done and
